options.label: A

title: The strange case of the cyclops sheep - Tien Nguyen

multiple-choice.question: What was the unusual deformity observed in the sheep born in Idaho in the 1950s?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: As a treatment for eye cancer

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: A brief history of banned numbers - Alessandra King

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question: Who was the mathematician who discovered irrational numbers and was allegedly punished by the Pythagoreans?
Conceptual Question: What was the Pythagorean's notion of a perfect universe based on?

Analytical Question: What is the significance of the concept of zero in the Hindu-Arabic numeral system?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for the representation of negative numbers and facilitates the recording of debt

options.label: B
options.text: It enables the calculation of square roots

options.label: C
options.text: It makes it easier to find solutions to cubic and quartic equations

options.text: The idea that numbers can be used to express protected information, such as copyrights or state secrets

options.label: A
options.text: That numbers are only useful for mathematical calculations

options.label: B
options.text: That numbers are a way of expressing concepts and information, and are becoming increasingly important in our lives

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: That numbers are only useful for artistic expression

multiple-choice.question: Factual Question: When did the study of numbers become well-developed in Ancient Greece?

options.label: B
options.text: The power of numbers, as calculations and algorithms shape more and more of our lives

title: Should we get rid of standardized testing? - Arlo Kempf

multiple-choice.question: Where were the first standardized tests administered over 2,000 years ago?

options.label: B
options.text: In China during the Han dynasty

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of standardized tests in evaluating stair climbs for firefighters in France?

options.label: B
options.text: To determine aptitude for various government posts

options.label: C
options.text: To compare the time of the climb to that of all other firefighters

options.label: D
options.text: To measure abstract characteristics or skills

options.label: B
options.text: A measure of abstract characteristics or skills

options.label: C
options.text: A way to express results of a test, where 70% of test takers scored below or above the test taker

multiple-choice.question: What are two critical ideas for understanding standardized tests?
What is the difference between a reliable and an invalid thermometer?

options.label: A
options.text: A reliable thermometer gives consistent readings, while an invalid thermometer gives different readings

options.label: B
options.text: A reliable thermometer gives different readings, while an invalid thermometer gives consistent readings

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: A reliable thermometer is consistently too hot, while an invalid thermometer gives different readings

options.label: B
options.text: A tool for measuring the circumference of an object

options.label: C
options.text: A tool that may measure the wrong things if it's given the wrong job or not designed properly

options.label: D
options.text: A tool for measuring abstract characteristics or skills

options.label: A
options.text: They are too difficult to measure

options.label: B
options.text: They are too easy to measure

options.label: C
options.text: They are not reliable or valid

options.label: D
options.text: They are not necessary to measure

options.label: A
options.text: A ruler measures length, while a standardized test measures temperature

options.label: B
options.text: A ruler measures length, while a standardized test measures the circumference of an object

options.label: C
options.text: A ruler is a tool, while a standardized test is a person

options.label: D
options.text: A ruler is a person, while a standardized test is a tool

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with interpreting results of a standardized test?

options.label: B
options.text: It's too easy to interpret results

options.label: C
options.text: It's up to the test takers to interpret results

options.label: D
options.text: It's up to the person administering the test to interpret results

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: To help teachers learn a little about a lot of students in a short time

multiple-choice.question: What is the concern of social scientists about test scores resulting in sweeping and often negative changes for test takers?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They are too easy to implement

options.label: C
options.text: They can have long-term life consequences

options.label: D
options.text: They are not necessary to implement

multiple-choice.question: What is the responsibility of educators when using standardized tests?

options.label: C
options.text: To use the right tests for the right jobs and interpret results appropriately

title: How do executive orders work? - Christina Greer

multiple-choice.question: What is an executive order?

options.label: B
options.text: A decision made by a federal judge

options.label: C
options.text: A bill proposed by a member of Congress

options.label: D
options.text: An order issued by the president without consultation or permission from Congress

multiple-choice.question: How many executive orders did FDR issue?
What was the purpose of FDR's 1942 executive order?

options.label: A
options.text: To establish requirements for nondiscriminatory practices in hiring and employment

options.label: D
options.text: To target predominantly Japanese-Americans, as well as German-Americans and Italian-Americans for internment

multiple-choice.question: What happens to an executive order when the president leaves office?

options.label: C
options.text: It can be eliminated by the successor president

options.label: D
options.text: It remains in effect until it is overturned by a court or Congress

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most famous executive orders in American history?

options.label: A
options.text: Harry Truman's executive order to desegregate the armed forces

options.label: B
options.text: FDR's executive order to establish the Works Progress Administration

options.label: C
options.text: Lyndon Johnson's executive order to establish requirements for nondiscriminatory practices in hiring and employment

multiple-choice.question: Why do presidents often use executive orders?

options.label: C
options.text: To exert power without working with Congress

options.label: D
options.text: To clarify and help implement policies

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the checks and balances in the U.S. political system?

options.label: A
options.text: Congress can pass laws to counteract executive orders

options.label: B
options.text: Judges can halt executive orders by deeming them unconstitutional

options.label: C
options.text: The president can go into effect immediately

multiple-choice.question: How can an executive order be enforced?

options.label: A
options.text: It can be enforced like a law

options.label: B
options.text: It can be enforced by the court system

options.label: C
options.text: It can be enforced by Congress

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the limitations of an executive order?

options.label: A
options.text: It can only be issued in times of crisis

options.label: B
options.text: It can only be used to expand the power of federal agencies

options.label: C
options.text: It can be subject to judicial review by the court system

options.label: D
options.text: It can only be issued by the president

multiple-choice.question: How has the power of executive orders expanded over time?

options.label: C
options.text: It has expanded due to the ambiguity of the U.S. Constitution

options.label: D
options.text: It has been limited by Congress

title: What are gravitational waves? - Amber L. Stuver

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The explosion of a nearby planet

options.label: C
options.text: The merger into a single, even bigger black hole

options.label: D
options.text: Being stretched sideways while being compressed vertically, then stretched up and down while being compressed horizontally, and experiencing this back-and-forth motion

is a duplicate question so it has been removed.

options.label: C
options.text: The mass and shape of objects that generated the waves

options.label: D
options.text: To study the properties of space-time

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the length of the arms of a gravitational wave detector like LIGO when a gravitational wave passes through it?
According to the text, what is the name of the sound produced by two black holes colliding?

title: Where do new words come from? - Marcel Danesi

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many new words are added to the Oxford English Dictionary every year?

options.label: C

What is the term for the process by which ideas and symbols propagate through a culture, like genes through a population, and is also a term for a certain kind of image?
What is the term for the phenomenon of words that describe themselves?
What is the primary role of dictionaries in documenting current usage of words?

options.label: A
options.text: They give official names to new discoveries and technologies

options.label: B
options.text: They make decisions about new words

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of adenosine in the human body?

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the concentration of plutonium.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main danger associated with spent fuel?

options.label: B
options.text: Plutonium can sustain a chain reaction and can be mined from the waste to make bombs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a coolant in a nuclear reactor?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the concentration of U-235.

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease the concentration of fission products.

options.label: C
options.text: To capture the heat generated by fission and transfer it to a steam turbine.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the concentration of plutonium.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge for a nuclear reactor to safely contain the products of fission?

options.label: C
options.text: The radioactive fission products in these vapors eventually decay into stable elements.

options.label: D
options.text: The containment building may fail to hold the radioactive gas pressure.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of storing spent fuel in pools of water?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the concentration of U-235.

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease the concentration of fission products.

options.label: C
options.text: To cool the waste and block its radioactive emissions.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the concentration of plutonium.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge for a nation to plan to guard plutonium through its radioactive half-life of 24,000 years?

options.label: C
options.text: The long-term security of deep time storage in tunnels drilled far underground.

options.label: D
options.text: The short-term security of storing spent fuel on site.

multiple-choice.question: Who should be the watchmen to guard spent fuel?

options.label: D
options.text: The nuclear industry as a whole
